snippet: Factors conspiring to make retirement difficult if not impossible, including low interest rates and fewer defined-benefit pensions, are keeping workers over 62 at their jobs.
abstract: Floyd Norris Off the Charts column notes younger workers are being crowded out as older Americans cling to jobs longer, working well past typical retirement age for various reasons; more people in their 60s and 70s are working than before Great Recession, but employment among young people is off sharply.
lead_paragraph: Factors conspiring to make retirement difficult if not impossible, including low interest rates and fewer defined-benefit pensions, are keeping workers over 62 at their jobs.

headline.print_headline: The Older Cling to Jobs, Crowding Out the Younger
headline.main: The Older Cling to Jobs, Crowding Out the Younger
